etymologies: early 17th century: from Latin refract- ‘broken up’, from the verb refringere, from re- ‘back’ + frangere ‘to break’

definitions: (of water, air, or glass) make (a ray of light) change direction when it enters at an angle

examples.text: the rays of light are refracted by the material of the lens

shortDefinitions: (of water, air, or glass) make ray of light change direction when it enters at angle

definitions: measure the focusing characteristics of (an eye) or of the eyes of (someone)

examples.text: when refracting patients an ophthalmologist relies on verbal reports

shortDefinitions: measure focusing characteristics of eye or of eyes of
